meanings.definition: To make or become more intense or stronger.
meanings.sent1: She wanted to intensify the colors of the painting by adding more red and yellow.
meanings.sent2: The storm began to intensify, with the wind picking up speed and the rain falling harder.
meanings.sent3: Trying to intensify the flavor of the soup, she accidentally added too much salt.
meanings.sent4: His anger seemed to intensify with each passing minute, like a volcano ready to erupt.
meanings.sent5: The music seemed to intensify the emotions in the room, making everyone feel more alive.

meanings.definition: To increase in degree or strength.
meanings.sent1: The company decided to intensify their marketing efforts to reach more customers.
meanings.sent2: The heat of the sun began to intensify as the day progressed.
meanings.sent3: His excitement started to intensify as he got closer to the finish line.
meanings.sent4: The tension in the room seemed to intensify, creating a palpable sense of unease.
meanings.sent5: The smell of fresh bread baking in the oven started to intensify, filling the house with a warm aroma.

meanings.definition: To heighten or deepen in effect.
meanings.sent1: The medication may intensify the side effects if taken with alcohol.
meanings.sent2: The use of lighting can intensify the mood of a scene in a movie.
meanings.sent3: His attempt to intensify the joke by adding a funny gesture only made it more awkward.
meanings.sent4: The silence in the room seemed to intensify, making every sound more noticeable.
meanings.sent5: The smell of smoke started to intensify, signaling that the fire was getting closer.
